articles.title: Joint replacement pioneer Dr. Kenneth Krackow dies
articles.summary: Kenneth Krackow, MD, a pioneer of joint replacement and arthroplasty procedures, died Jan. 9.

articles.title: 10 systems seeking supply chain leaders
articles.summary: As hospitals redefine the role of supply chain leaders to focus on enterprise strategy, digital transformation and resilience, health systems across the country are hiring for senior-level supply chain positions. The jobs reflect a growing shift in expectations, from traditional procurement toward broader responsibilities in value-based care, system integration and analytics-driven operations.

articles.title: Labor Department proposes PBM compensation disclosure rule for self-insured plans
articles.summary: The Labor Department’s Employee Benefits Security Administration proposed regulation Jan. 29 that would require pharmacy benefit managers to disclose their compensation with self-insured group health plans.

articles.title: Luigi Mangione won’t face death penalty, judge rules
articles.summary: A federal judge has ruled that Luigi Mangione will not face the death penalty in the federal case stemming from the killing of UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson. On Jan.

articles.title: 2 X-ray systems recalled over mechanical, software defects
articles.summary: Two interventional fluoroscopic X-ray systems were recalled in separate Class II events due to safety issues affecting image acquisition and mechanical movement, according to FDA notices posted Jan. 27.

articles.title: California hospital upgrades radiology services
articles.summary: Loma Linda (Calif.) University Medical Center-Murrieta began using a new CT scanner earlier this month, marking a major upgrade to its diagnostic imaging capabilities.

articles.title: Intermountain Health to freeze pension plan
articles.summary: Salt Lake City-based Intermountain Health plans to freeze its pension plan at the end of 2026 and shift affected employees to a 401(k)-based retirement program. The system said the decision is driven by ongoing financial pressures, including lower government reimbursement, inflation and market volatility.

articles.summary: The proposal would mark a significant change for the secretive PBM industry, which often shields crucial data from its clients.

articles.title: How direct-to-consumer health tests could impact insurance, mortgages, and employment
articles.summary: As more consumers order up lab tests and genetic screenings, experts say it could impact insurance, loans, and employment decisions.

Nourish to offer free lab testing for members to inform nutrition care
articles.summary: Nourish Labs will integrate blood testing into personalized nutrition care. The objective measurement will improve treatment plans and strengthen patient engagement, executives say.

articles.title: Maven Clinic launches research institute focused on digital health, collaboration
articles.summary: The institute will serve as a platform for partnerships across academia and industry while expanding the scope of women’s and family health research, Maven Clinic says.

articles.title: Senate Democrats strike deal with White House to keep government funded: media reports
articles.summary: Legislation that includes funding for HHS and Medicare telehealth extensions is now in peril as Senate Democrats hardened their stance on Department of Homeland Security funding.

articles.title: More than 75 health systems call for stepped-up oversight of patient data sharing
articles.summary: More than 75 health systems sent a letter to federal officials raising concerns about the integrity of nationwide data sharing networks, flagging issues with "bad actors" gaining access to patients' medical information.

articles.title: KFF: Nearly 53M prior auth requests submitted in Medicare Advantage in 2024
articles.summary: A new study shows that close to 53 million prior authorization requests were sent to Medicare Advantage plans in 2024, increasing from 2023 and far above the number required in traditional Medicare.
